title: I Dont Give A Shit If This Is A Normal Game
body: Feeding because you're "having fun" isn't exactly making the game fun at all

replies.body: There is a difference between int feeding and having an off game and asking to not be flamed because it's a normal game
If it's an off game, then no need to flame even if it is a ranked game...  normal game irrelevant.
If you want to focus on winning then play Ranked.

simply put, it's all a competition where the fun is in trying to win unless you are completely among friends and can then do whatever you want.

for example, I learned that in ranked, people spam the most overpowered nonsense they can think of and tend to have advantages over the typical player

I prefer normals because it is still competitive...but not all-out crazy that some players just have an advantage with both knowledge of their champs and a finite pool of champions as their IP climbs to afford runes

I met a pantheon in a mirror match once in dominion....we started exactly the same...and he had 15-20 more armor and magic resist, so he won every trade

But it isn't competitive.............  People literally don't care if they win or lose because normals is used to have fun, practice offmeta/nonviable builds/comps, and to just generally work on mechanics.

Winning or losing isn't a big part of it, and while a inter is still a problem, someone having a bad game and not caring is pretty normal.

If I take AD Xerath top lane, it my not go so well, but I don't want to get flamed because they have every chance to dodge(I give people a warning), to play something just as crazy, or to choose  **an entire mode designed for competitive play where winning and losing is the only thing that matters.**

I wouldn't be surprised if 90% of the player base gained an idea of what was good on champs based on just mimicing what their friends do as opposed to actually understanding how all the stats interact.  From that perspective, AD Xerath doesn't seem like a bad idea since he's got an AA just like anyone else and all AA scale off of AD.

If your friends build Xerath AP, every ally you play with builds Xerath AP, every enemy you see builds Xerath AP, the enemy Xerath Bot in Coop v AI builds AP, and you launch the game to see that all of Xerath's recommended items are Mana or AP items, and you STILL try to build him AD without researching it after having already made it to level 30, then maybe you just aren't smart enough to play LoL.

Actually, you have it in reverse. Bot matches are for practicing things.  The only kind of "practice" you can get from a pvp match that bots (which exist for the sole purpose of allowing people to practice and get mechanically better) is learning to play against human opponents. However, since human's are as unpredictable and varied in thought processes as they are there's not really much one can do to improve that "skill" other than just being capable of adapting to things quickly which is a natural talent that can't be improved on all that much so claiming that it's used for practicing that is simply ludicrous. Also, they added a sandbox mode for people who feel they need to practice things. There are modes specifically made for practicing. The reason they exist is so that people can't selfishly claim that the normal games are for them to "practice" so that the people who got the game for, and here's a mindblowing concept, fun can actually have fun with the game. If you want your gotta win stress then there are places for that. As for normals, no one is going to care how pissed you are that your little practice session isn't going the way you specifically want it to. That's where that adaptation I was talking about comes in. You either change up your perspective of the situation, or continue to be frustrated at it. Those are really the only two options. The other options aren't going to care.

Winning is the point of any game mode. The difference is how you're supposed to accomplish victory.

You don't get the right to not care about winning if you're playing Normals and think it's fine because this game mode is less serious than Ranked. What if i am in a Normal game to practice a champion with the intent to play it in Ranked? No it's not.  People play videogames to have fun.  If you have fun winning and optimizing your chance of winning then play Ranked.  If you would just like to win but not really be tryhard about it then play Unranked.

Other people goofing off doesn't inhibit your practice of a champion.  If anything, oddball stuff helps you more because it helps highlight how your champion performs in edge cases and forces you to understand what your champ is good or bad at in various scenarios.  Learning to be flexible is crucial in Ranked play.

League, as a game that incorporates a PvP environment. Is a competition.
Since any queue has Matchmaking, every queue also has its own MMR ladder (probably not RGM).

 No matter which queue you're playing, there are no draws. One team will win, one will lose. "Tryharding" isn't a term.
